channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: India and China, Besieged by Air Pollution
item.description: India’s air pollution is often worse than the levels recorded in China, but in China there’s much more awareness of the problem.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Graham Crouch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Heavy smog shrouding New Delhi on a recent January day.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Reports Problem With Its Lunar Rover
item.description: The Jade Rabbit, which had an anticipated life span of three months, has experienced a “mechanical control abnormality” that could prevent it from carrying out further lunar exploration.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Stock Sell-Off Continues as Markets Sink
item.description: Investors are fretting about slowing growth in China and the prospect that the Fed will continue to scale back support of the United States economy.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By BETTINA WASSENER

item.title: Militants Down Egyptian Helicopter, Killing 5 Soldiers
item.description: Islamist militants shot down an Egyptian military helicopter in the Sinai Peninsula with a surface-to-air missile over the weekend, raising new alarms about the terrorist insurgency there.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Mohamed Rashed/Almasry Alyoum, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Soldiers and relatives carried the coffin of Ahmed Abul Atta, an Egyptian pilot killed when a military helicopter was shot down on Saturday. An Islamist militant group claimed responsibility.

item.title: India Ink: On Bad Air Days in India, Staying Inside Doesn’t Help
item.description: Poor indoor air quality, along with outdoor pollution, may help explain why Indians have among the weakest lungs in the world.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:credit: Graham Crouch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Military force personnel manning a checkpoint in New Delhi in the early morning fog on Jan. 21.

item.title: Russians Debate Sticker Price of Sochi Games
item.description: Aleksei A. Navalny, the anticorruption blogger, has compiled a detailed report of Russia’s Olympic spending which he believes is much higher than the figure the Kremlin officials have reported.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: Workers construct the Olympic rings during heavy snow at the Lauea Cross-Country Ski and Biathlon Center about 17 miles north of Sochi, Russia.

item.title: South Korea Proposes Dates for Family Reunions With North
item.description: The reunions are a sign of slightly warming ties between the two Koreas after Pyongyang called for better relations.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Japan Official Under Fire for Saying Public Broadcaster Won’t Criticize Government
item.description: Some members of the news media questioned whether NHK, Japan’s influential public broadcaster, was under political pressure to adhere to the views of the right-leaning government.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: U.S. Weighs Sanctions in Central Africa
item.description: The United States is deeply concerned about the escalation of religious violence in Central African Republic, where at least 18 people have been killed in recent days.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Airstrike Is Said to Kill Shabab Figure
item.description: A Somali rebel commander blamed the United States for a missile strike that he said killed Sahal Iskudhuq, a militant who was believed to be close to the Shabab’s top leader.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Memo From Paris: After President’s Breakup, French Wonder if Role of First Lady Is Passé
item.description: The French are sounding fed up with the idea of a first lady in the days after François Hollande’s announcement of the end of his relationship with his longtime companion.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and MAÏA de la BAUME
item.media:description: Valérie Trierweiler, the former companion of the French president, François Hollande, after her arrival in Mumbai on Monday.

item.title: In South Korea, Spam Is the Stuff Gifts Are Made Of
item.description: Since the Korean War, the gelatinous meat product has remained a part of the fabric of culinary life in even the most stylish enclaves of South Korea.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Cho Woohae for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Seoul, a special edition Spam gift set for Lunar New Year.

item.title: The Influential Minister Behind Argentina’s Economic Shift
item.description: Axel Kicillof, appointed as Argentina’s economy minister in November, has been thrust into the spotlight as much for his sense of style as his policies.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO and JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:description: Argentina’s President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner with Axel Kicillof, the economy minister, at his swearing-in ceremony in November.

item.title: Afghanistan Exit Is Seen as Peril to Drone Mission
item.description: American intelligence agencies are concerned that they could lose their air bases used for drone strikes if a final security deal cannot be struck with the Afghan president, Hamid Karzai.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Defiance by President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan has lent new credence to an option.

item.title: Afghan Villagers Brought to Back Airstrike Report
item.description: At a news conference to bolster the Afghan government’s account of an American airstrike, villagers identify a 2009 photo as one from this month.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A resident of Wazghar, which was hit by an airstrike this month, spoke at a news conference called Sunday by officials in Kabul.

item.title: Syria Willing to Let Some Leave Area It Barricaded
item.description: A plan by the government to allow women and children to leave the city of Homs raised concerns that men who try to do so would be arrested.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Three Years After Uprising, Tunisia Approves Constitution
item.description: The country’s Assembly voted its approval on Sunday, completing a two-year drafting process and ushering in a new democratic era.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Peace Deal to End Insurgency Came After Philippine Leader’s Ultimatum to Rebels
item.description: President Benigno S. Aquino III made it clear to Muslim rebels that the peace deal he was offering was the best they could expect from any Philippine leader.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: Ukraine Protests Spread as Overture Is Spurned
item.description: The growing unrest raised the prospect of widening violence and deepening political chaos while leaders in Kiev, the capital, remain at an impasse.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Ukrainians in Kiev gathered Sunday at the coffin of Mikhail Zhiznevsky, 25, who was one of three protesters shot to death last week during clashes with the police in the capital.

item.title: U.N. Inquiry Criticizes Qatar’s Justice System
item.description: A critique concludes that prosecutors and judges need more autonomy, defense lawyers should have more access to evidence, and foreign suspects may be vulnerable to discrimination.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Polish Church’s Gender Problem
item.description: For years, the church showed no interest in "gender ideology." Now it speaks of little else.
item.dc:creator: By SLAWOMIR SIERAKOWSKI

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Confessions of the Cultural Revolution
item.description: As the vitriolic reaction to Song Binbin's apology shows, China is not ready for a public reckoning.
item.dc:creator: By XIAO HAN

item.title: Himmler Papers Shed Light on Personal Life of a Nazi
item.description: Excerpts from a collection of letters, diaries and photographs from Heinrich Himmler, chief of the Nazi Gestapo, and his family have been published for the first time.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Realworks Ltd/Die Welt, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo from 1935 showing Heinrich Himmler with his wife, Marga, his son, Gerhard, his daughter, Gudrun, center, and an unidentified friend in Bavaria.

item.title: International Education: Raising Asian Awareness of the Holocaust
item.description: The Hong Kong Holocaust and Tolerance Center, formed in 2011, is working to promote education about the Holocaust.
item.dc:creator: By YENNI KWOK
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students at St. Paul's Secondary School in Hong Kong listened to Olga Horak, a concentration camp survivor, on Jan. 22.

item.title: China Sentences Xu Zhiyong, Legal Activist, to 4 Years in Prison
item.description: The case against Mr. Xu, who campaigned against corruption and injustice, was seen as a barometer of how China’s new leadership would respond to organized calls for reform.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Zhang Qingfang, center, a lawyer for the prominent legal activist Xu Zhiyong, spoke to journalists after a court sentenced Mr. Xu to four years in prison.
